messages.content:
Or I should do something like this `const mustCount = notFinished.equals(Bool(true)).equals(action.isValid.equals(Bool(true)));
`  ?
Can do `Bool.And(notFinished, action.isValid)` I think.  Something like that.  But yeah, I would assume the problem here is using `&&` with circuits.
`Circuit.if(mustCount && action.positive` => `Circuit.if(Bool.And(mustCount, action.positive)`
Mmm, ok. yes I suppose that is the problem. But I think I have seen some example using `&&` . Anyway will do it the right way. Thanks again !
Which examples?
Dont have them on my mind right now. Just think I saw some example where it was used when browsing code ,,, not important anyway.
For the docs https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/snarkyjs-reference/classes/Bool#and I assume will have to be `notFinished.and(isValid)`

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

messages.content: There are both static and instance versions of the methods it looks like.  I'm not sure if there is a performance difference 🤷‍♂️
Trying it now ...

One of the most frustrating things about snarkyJS is how things perform differently in the proof than in javascript.  Using `&&` could be fine in some circumstances, or someone might have written code that passed a test with proofs off and published it as an example.  In general, you have to be _extremely_ cautious not to use variable-length arrays or branching logic since it's so natural in other contexts.
Nice work!
Yes, really. It is really confusing sometimes. One has to remember that were are not really writing JS here, and is difficult to remember that all the time 🙂

Well, yes I have seen a lot of examples with proofs off. I have set it on in all my test cases. Some weeks ago I spent many hours with something that worked ok on Local and not on Berkeley, and the issue was I was not using proofs on Local. NEVER AGAIN jaja
Well leaving proofs on slows things down sometimes.  But it depends.  It can speed things up in the long run if it saves you from making mistakes.
Agree. Good to disable them for a quick test eventually. What time is there, working late ? Its past midnight here ...

One of my ideas for cohort 2, which I have no idea how to build but just think is a good idea, is some kind of visual interpretation of proofs.  If you can visually define your proof, it will be easy to spot branching logic, or other dynamic behaviors.
Almost midnight here!  I'm in east coast USA
I am at UTC-3, Buenos Aires. So I think its 2 hours difference.
It is quite a good idea, and it is just a "circuit" so graphical representation should be quite viable. I think that one would have to look at what Snarky produced to extract that info
So far, but basically the same time 😄
I thought so too, but some others reminded me how many constraints actually go into the proof.  I guess the trick is to show enough information without being too noisy.
I suppose that enabling different filtering levels may be possible, so you can hide some redundant constraints and get a cleaner picture
Anyway not an easy task 🙂
